item.title: Cuba Cracks Down on Protests in Wake of Worst Economic Crisis in Decades
item.description: President Obama abstained from a symbolic UN vote opposing the US’ embargo on Cuba for the first time in US history, signaling a move to repair relations. President Biden has yet to reverse any of the Trump admin’s decisions. But when Trump took office, he took a harder line and placed more sanctions on the country.

item.title: This Year’s All-Star Game Gets More Political
item.description: The backstory: In April, the MLB said it was moving the All-Star Game from Georgia to Denver due to Georgia’s new voting law. Either way, Denver businesses are happy to play host. Zoom out: A tourism board in Georgia said losing the game cost Georgia $100+ million in economic activity, though MLB estimates are slightly lower.

item.title: Delta Causes Fresh Lockdowns and Higher Caseloads Across the World
item.description: Boosters are hereFacing rising cases, this week Israel will become the first country in the world to administer a third Covid-19 booster vaccine shot; it’ll be given to adults with serious preexisting conditions. “We just want people to stay at home. Experts warn that the number of deaths could soon rise in unvaccinated areas of the country, but for now they’re down 27% on average nationwide from two weeks ago. In the US, which is more or less fully reopened for business, cases rose 47% last week, the biggest increase since April 2020.

item.title: Musk Faces Legal Questions Over SolarCity Acquisition
item.description: As Reuters asks, “Does Elon Musk control Tesla Inc., or does Tesla control Elon Musk?” so how was this bad for Tesla shareholders exactly? Musk didn’t need much due diligence before buying SolarCity—after all, his cousins founded it in 2006 and Musk served as the chairman.  The detailsThe lawsuit alleges that Tesla’s acquisition of SolarCity reeked with conflicts of interest and that Musk failed to disclose liquidity problems at SolarCity.

item.title: Branson in Space: Risky or Reckless?
item.description: His personal ambitions are intertwined with the company’s—this space flight was inevitable.    Micron shares fell more than 6% following the news of Appleton’s death. A 2011 study found that CEOs with licenses to pilot small aircraft (an activity 30x more dangerous than driving a car) are 40% more likely to make a corporate acquisition and 15% more likely to take on greater leverage. The company has completed more than 20 test flights, but the mission has been delayed by technical issues and a pilot died in a test flight in 2014. Bottom line: When Richard Branson decided to create a space company, it’s probably because he wanted to go to space.

item.title: Biden Signs Executive Order to Promote Fair Competition
item.description: So he signed a beefy executive order yesterday containing 72 measures meant to target big business and promote competition in the US economy. and more, “Here’s a guide to what I think,” reflects the Biden administration's focus on slowing corporate consolidation in order to help the US consumer.   The executive order mentions everything from shipping fees to over-the-counter hearing aids to banking mergers. Joe Biden is tired of other presidents getting all the “trustbuster” recognition in the history books.

item.title: China Tightens Regulations On Its Tech Companies
item.description: The change would force companies classified under a certain corporate structure (known as the Variable Interest Entity model if you want to sound smart af) to seek the government’s approval before listing shares in the US or Hong Kong. Hong Kong could soon become the only place for non-Chinese investors to buy stakes in Chinese tech companies as regulators throttle firms listed in the US. When Didi decided to go public anyway last week, the government halted new app downloads and user signups in China.
